name: Maya - Chaac

sections.content:
Among the oldest and most widely worshipped deities of the Maya, Chaac is the god of rain, thunder,
                and lightning. With his distinctive long nose and jade ornaments, he wields a great lightning axe
                to split the clouds and release the waters that sustain all life. As the lord of agriculture and
                fertility, Chaac was essential to Maya survival, his favor bringing bountiful harvests and his
                anger devastating droughts. His goggle-eyed visage adorns countless temples across the Maya world.

fourChaacs.description: Like many Maya deities, Chaac manifested as four distinct gods associated with the cardinal directions, each bringing different types of rain and associated with different colors.
fourChaacs.eastChaac: Chac Xib Chaac (East, Red): The red Chaac of the east, bringer of the first rains at dawn
fourChaacs.northChaac: Sac Xib Chaac (North, White): The white Chaac of the north, associated with cool winds and gentle rain
fourChaacs.westChaac: Ek Xib Chaac (West, Black): The black Chaac of the west, bringer of stormy rains at sunset
fourChaacs.southChaac: Kan Xib Chaac (South, Yellow): The yellow Chaac of the south, associated with warm rains
fourChaacs.cosmicSignificance: Together, these four Chaacs ensured that rain fell across all the Maya lands, each responsible for the weather in their quarter of the world. This quadripartite division reflects the Maya understanding of sacred space and cosmic order.

lightningAxe.description: Chaac's most famous attribute is his great axe (chaahk ax), which he uses to split open the clouds and release the rain.
lightningAxe.thunderAndLightning: When he strikes the clouds with this weapon, the resulting crack produces thunder, and the flash of the axe creates lightning. This stone axe is often depicted as a serpentine object, connecting Chaac to serpent symbolism throughout Maya thought.
lightningAxe.mountainOfSustenance: In some myths, Chaac also uses his axe to split open the Mountain of Sustenance, releasing maize for humanity - a story shared with the Aztec Tlaloc.

chaChaakCeremony.description: This ancient rain-calling ceremony survived Spanish colonization and continues among modern Maya communities.
chaChaakCeremony.conductor: Conducted by a h-men (ritual specialist), the ceremony typically involves an altar representing the cosmos, offerings of food and drink, and prayers to the four Chaacs at the cardinal directions.
chaChaakCeremony.frogParticipants: Young boys often participate, croaking like frogs to call the rain - frogs being considered Chaac's messengers and heralds.

worship.cenoteOfferings: Jade, precious objects, and sacrifices cast into sacred wells
worship.caveCeremonies: Rituals conducted in caves, considered entrances to Chaac's realm
worship.agriculturalRites: Planting and harvest ceremonies invoking rain blessings
worship.autoSacrifice: Blood offerings to petition for rain
worship.humanSacrifice: During severe droughts, humans were sacrificed to cenotes

cenotes.description: The Yucatan Peninsula is dotted with cenotes - natural limestone sinkholes filled with groundwater.
cenotes.significance: The Maya considered these sacred wells to be entrances to the watery underworld where Chaac and other water deities dwelt.
cenotes.sacredCenote: The most famous, the Sacred Cenote at Chichen Itza, received offerings for over a thousand years - jade, gold, pottery, and human sacrifices cast into its depths to secure Chaac's favor.

cosmology.underworldConnection: Caves and cenotes served as portals between the earthly realm and the watery domain of Chaac

namesAndMeanings.scholarlyDesignation: God B in the Schellhas classification system
namesAndMeanings.aztecEquivalent: Tlaloc (both rain gods with goggle eyes)

puucStyleArchitecture.description: Chaac reached his greatest architectural prominence in the Puuc region of Yucatan during the Terminal Classic period (800-1000 CE).
puucStyleArchitecture.sites: Sites like Uxmal, Kabah, Sayil, and Labna feature elaborate facades covered with hundreds of Chaac masks, their distinctive long noses projecting from temple walls.
puucStyleArchitecture.codzPoop: The Codz Poop ('rolled mat' or 'mask palace') at Kabah displays over 250 Chaac masks covering its entire facade - one of the most dramatic expressions of devotion to any deity in Mesoamerican architecture.

iconography.longNose: Chaac's most distinctive feature - a curved, elongated nose possibly representing a lightning bolt or serpent
iconography.goggleEyes: Large, circular eyes similar to Tlaloc, possibly representing clouds, rain, or serpent coils
iconography.lightningAxe: His primary weapon, often serpent-shaped, used to split clouds and create thunder
iconography.jadeOrnaments: Associated with water and preciousness, often shown with jade ear spools and pectorals

extendedContent.modernSignificance: Chaac remains one of the most enduring figures of Maya religion. The ch'a chaak ceremony is still performed when rains fail, demonstrating over two thousand years of continuous religious practice. Climate change has given Chaac renewed relevance as Maya farmers face increasingly unpredictable weather patterns.
